Award.AbstractNarration:
A request is made to fund new and replacement instrumentation for the R/V Oceanus, a 177? research vessel operated by Oregon State University as part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) research fleet.

The R/V Oceanus is a general-purpose research vessel owned by the National Science Foundation and operated by Oregon State University. Until 2012, the vessel had been operated by Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution but was then retired. OSU determined that the vessel was in better material condition than their ship R/V Wecoma so they took Oceanus and retired Wecoma. The mission of the ship is to support funded science research in the Pacific Northwest. R/V Oceanus completed 205 days in 2015, 126 (61%) of which were for NSF. In 2016, the vessel is scheduled to sail 196 days with 77% (151 days) of the schedule for NSF. With this proposal, OSU provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation:

1) Triaxus Cable Housing $6,000
2) Altimeter $3,286
3) Triaxus Computer System $5,000
$14,286

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The OSU Marine Technician Group was awarded $14,286 for Fiber Optic termination supplies, an altimeter and computer system. The OSU Marine Technician Group has utilized these funds to purchase fully supplied fiber optic tool kit, a Valport altimeter and a high performing computer system. This entire award has been spent out on these items. These items will help to bring the Triaxus vehicle to operational capacity if needed in the future, and in the meantime they have increased the capabilities of the OSU Marine Technician Group. Two team members of the OSU Marine Technician Group attended a comprehensive fiber optics training class hosted by the University of Deleware  in 2017 which allowed them to have the knowledge of selecting the appropriate tools to build a fiber optic tool kit.bThe Valport altimeters have been thoroughly tested on the R/V Oceanus’s CTD system and have proven to be reliable and high performing sensors. A Mac Pro computer system was chosen due to its well known high performance and UDIMM RAM which is high speed and preferred by many scientists for accuracy in data collection. The OSU Marine Technician Group remains fully capable of bringing the Triaxus vehicle system to full operational capacity, if it is needed in the future. 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/03/2018
Modified by: Andrew W Woogen
